item.title: Design Justice - Book
item.description: Information Source: [[Sasha Costanza-Chock]] Tags: #design #technology #innovation #nonfiction #society #education Notes: [[Miscellaneous Notes/Literature Notes/Design Justice - Literature Notes]] Reboot Summary Design justice also focuses on the ==design of systems== Design justice rethinks design processes, centers people who are normally marginalized by design, and uses collaborative, creative practices to address the deepest challenges our communities face.

item.title: A Pig Was Once Killed in Our Garage - Book
item.description: Information Source: [[Martin Villanueva]] Tags: #essays Notes: [[A Pig Was Once Killed in Our Garage (Literature Notes)]] Highlights “What I write here is not my teaching, but my study; it is not a lesson for others, but for me.

item.title: 13 Principles of Web3 - Thread
item.description: Information Source: [[David Phelps]]; https://twitter.com/divine_economy/status/1454218925483384834 Tags: #web3 Notes: Highlights Web 3 can transform everyday instutions. Each reveals a fundamental principle of what Web3 means.

item.title: 1a1 - The age of the linked note
item.description: [[Atlas/Maps/LYT 10 MOC]] Before recently, a note was just a note. A note was something you took quickly, used, and tossed.

item.title: 1a2 - Why make notes
item.description: [[Atlas/Maps/LYT 10 MOC]] Why do you care about making digital notes? Like, what are you actually trying to accomplish? That’s not an easy thing to answer.

item.title: 1a3 - Fall of the note taker
item.description: [[Atlas/Maps/LYT 10 MOC]] Our notes turned against us Our notes turned against us. After many years of taking notes, our collection of notes is more cluttered than ever, more overwhelming, more frustrating.

item.title: 1a4 - Rise of the note maker
item.description: [[Atlas/Maps/LYT 10 MOC]] Build notes that grow in value over time Most people take ==“just-in-time” notes.== They take them for a specific short-term purpose—like a test or a project.

item.title: 1b1 - The rigidity of a system with only folders
item.description: [[Atlas/Maps/LYT 10 MOC]] Let’s call that our traditional folder-only approach to file management. In terms of Systems, we can classify it as rigid, linear, and top-down.

item.title: 1b2 - Zettelkasten and the great folder rebellion
item.description: [[Atlas/Maps/LYT 10 MOC]] We can look to around 2008 as to when notes became FAST. And that was with the ==introduction of Evernote to the public.

item.title: 1b3 - Scaling zettlekasten
item.description: [[Atlas/Maps/LYT 10 MOC]] While the Zettelkasten Method has given us the power to make fast, atomic, and linked notes, ==it doesn’t naturally give us enough structure.

item.title: 1b4 - Idea Emergence - Part 1
item.description: [[Atlas/Maps/LYT 10 MOC]] In the past, to manage our files, we had a rigid folder-only system. As files became faster, we started calling them notes.

item.title: 1b5 - Idea Emergence - Part 2
1b6 - Defining fluid frameworks
item.description: Fluid frameworks are ==non-rigid, highly-flexible organizing structures== that you can use as needed. Within the LYT frameworks, we are mainly referring to higher-order notes like MOCs.

item.title: 1c1 - Making relationships between notes
item.description: How should I use tags? Or should I use them at all? Same with folders. Should I just abolish them and go with links only?

item.title: 1c2 - Building relationships with links
item.description: ![[Extras/Media/Images/Links as a relationship.png]] Direct links are the strongest type of relationship. They are the purest and most explicit way of connecting two notes.

item.title: 1c3 - Building relationships with folders
item.description: The death of folders has been greatly exaggerated. Folders separate information in a rigid way. This is their strength and their weakness.

item.title: 1c4 - Building relationships with tags
item.description: The death of tags has been greatly exaggerated. The problem is perspective. Again, we have Evernote to thank.

item.title: 1c5 - Building relationships with proximity
item.description: Here is perhaps our sneakiest relationship-building mechanism: Proximity. Everyone tends to overlook how proximity makes relationships between notes. Proximity can be random » Airplane flight sitting next to total strangers Proximity can be intentional » Airplane flight sitting next to your family There are 3 types of proximity.

item.title: 1c6 - Building relationships with MOCs
item.description: An MOC is just a note — a very special type of note. It has properties of folders and tags, while effectively leveraging proximity.

item.title: 1c7 - Building relationships with a home note
item.description: Think of your Home note as the ==highest-level of your digital notes.== It has links to the main MOCs in your library along with your most relevant tags.

item.title: 1c8 - Building relationships with queries
item.description: After you have a bunch of notes, you can strategically use queries to help you see your notes in a special way.

item.title: 2a2 - The time value of ideas
item.description: You have a choice: Get $100 today, or $100 in 12 months. Which do you choose? Most people choose “today”.

item.title: 2a3 - The value phase of each PKM
item.description: In our knowledge management: What makes something valuable? What activities generate the most value? How can we do more of the valuable stuff?

item.title: 2a4 - The compound effects of note-taking
item.description: In response to the Information Age, we have a choice: Try to collect Every. Single. Thing. That means collecting anything “just in case” it might be helpful in the future.

item.title: 2a5 - The compound effects of note-making
item.description: This second lesson will make the argument that spending time note-making (aka “Progressive Ideation”) creates great value, produces positive side effects, and is where you should be spending more (but not all) of your precious time.

item.title: 2b1 - The 3 paradigms of notes
item.description: What is a note? How do notes work? What can you do with notes? The answers can be understood through three paradigms.

item.title: 2b2 - Evergreen notes
item.description: Note-takers “churn and burn” through their notes. They take them for a specific short-term (“just-in-time”) purpose—like a test or a project.

item.title: 2b3 - Thing notes and statement notes
item.description: When it comes to notes about ideas, there are two types: Thing notes are concepts and any other noun-like “thing”.

item.title: 2d1 - How folder-based PKM systems restrict your thinking
item.description: Before we completely dive into the fluid thinking that’s enabled by using LYT frameworks, it helps to gain perspective by considering where we are coming from.

item.title: 2d2 - Fluid thinking is idea emergence plus systems thinking
item.description: Systems thinking To really take advantage of linking your thoughts together, it helps to know a little bit more about systems thinking.

item.title: 2d3 - Top-down bottom-up middle-out
item.description: Bottom-up: start with atomic notes Top-down: start with structure, like folders or MOCs Middle-out: happens when we’re spending our time in Emergence Level 3, where higher notes like MOCs are being assembled, collided, and unified Unifying Phase: merge/unify, navigate, reference what emerges is a valuable grouping of ideas.

item.title: 2x1 - Consider ways to find insights across relationships
item.description: Relationships are the area of the PKM Planet that makes people say, “Huh, I haven’t really thought about that.” The following is meant to show what is possible.

item.title: 3a1 - Generate thought collisions to develop valuable ideas
item.description: From a tightly-packed collision of clouds emerges intense electricity. We call this lightning. And from lightning comes illumination. These same set of conditions work for the ==generation of ideas.

item.title: 3a2 - Use MOCs to overcome mental squeeze points
item.description: A [[Mental Squeeze Point]] is ==when your unsorted knowledge becomes so messy it overwhelms and discourages you.== Either you are equipped with frameworks to overcome the squeeze point, or you are discouraged and possibly abandon your project.

item.title: 3a3 - MOCs are both workbenches and maps
item.description: Do you feel it? That feeling of overwhelm? That mental squeeze point? That’s when you need to become a map-maker and chart the terrain in a new MOC.

item.title: 3a4 - Defining higher order notes and MOCs
item.description: What is a note again? A note is any container of thought. We are all familiar with notes. But in the age of the linked note, there is a new type of note we can generally call a “higher-order” note.

item.title: 3a5 - The three phases of MOCs
item.description: Maps of Content (MOCs) are one of the ultimate thinking tools. They have three basic, overlapping phases. Assembling phase Assemble, collect, gather, curate, incubate Put related stuff on a new digital workbench.

item.title: 3b1 - The anatomy of MOCs
item.description: Let’s take the 7 C’s of note-making to the next level of Idea Emergence. Welcome to the many moves of the map-maker (which include ≈10 C’s by the way) !

item.title: 3b2 - The assembling phase
item.description: You walk around in the world. You encounter stuff. You want to do something with that stuff. What does that look like in your note-making space?

item.title: 3b3 - The colliding phase
item.description: Ideas are often forged in argument when opposing thoughts are set against each other. This is what happens when notes are placed in a room together and forced to figure things out.

item.title: 3b4 - The unifying phase
item.description: In the third phase of MOCs, we unify it with the rest of your note library. As you finish work on an area of interest, the MOC remains as a renewable summation of thought for Future You.

item.title: 3c1 - Use MOCs for developing your ideas
item.description: You can use MOCs for developing your ideas. We just covered this intensely in section 3b. I used my Habits MOC as an example.

item.title: 3c2 - Use MOCs for charting an area of interest
item.description: Topics are like cities. Spending time in a new topic is like spending time in a new city. If you have a good sense of the city, you will be able to navigate it much better.

item.title: 3c3 - Use MOCs for building cognitive scaffolding
item.description: Why have we been building our Concepts MOC note? The main reason is so you start building meaningful cognitive scaffolding in your note-making space.

item.title: 3c4 - Use MOCs for creating a personal field guide
item.description: Maybe you keep forgetting ways to fall asleep effectively. Maybe you want to remind Future You how to set goals, or how to follow a specific exercise regimen.

item.title: 3c5 - Use MOCs for grounding yourself
item.description: Let’s go deeper into the theme that “not all PKM should be about soulless efficiency”. The reason LYT exists is because I love thinking.

item.title: 3d1 - Five umbrella benefits of MOCs
item.description: These are the 5 overlapping umbrella benefits of making and using MOCs: Dependable — Flexible — Enhancing — Generating — Healthy

item.title: 3d2 - Fluid thinking is the goal
item.description: Now that we’ve had more practice, let’s revisit [[Cards/Idea Emergence]] and the skill of [[Fluid Thinking]]" Fluid thinking is the awareness and skill to think from the right level of abstraction at the right time.

item.title: 4a1 - Map your way home
item.description: All roads lead to home. But we haven’t finished all the roads yet. That’s what we will do in this unit.

item.title: 4a2 - Avoid costly structuring traps
item.description: Structure must be earned! But since you weren’t born yesterday, you might have a few ideas already. Just be careful not to over-structure too much too soon.

item.title: 4b1 - Connect your maps
item.description: Let’s relate our work to the levels of [[Cards/Idea Emergence]]. In the previous units: We created notes (Emergence Level 1) We connected notes (Emergence Level 2) We created MOCs (Emergence Level 3) Now let’s connect MOCs (Emergence Level 4) Exercise 🗺 Gather your MOCs into a new note called workbench.

item.title: 4b2 - Build your library
item.description: After making many MOCs, we start to desire a place to easily access them. We can accomplish this with two complementary notes: A library: This can be a time-tested pre-built solution.

item.title: 4b3 - Build your home
item.description: When it comes to feeling grounded, it’s just like what Dorothy said in The Wizard of Oz: “There’s no place like home.

item.title: 4c1 - Develop your PKM folders
item.description: In this section, we dive deeply into folders, tags, metadata, and queries. As a reminder, we looked at three of these PKM relationship-builders in Unit 1:

item.title: A Digtial Yggdrasil - Education as a Public Good - Proposal
item.description: Information Source: [[Qing Ze]] Tags: #web3 #education #publicgoods Notes: Highlights Web3’s Shared Challenge: Growing Our Own Timber We need to develop a system that onboards people to Web3 in meaningful ways enabling them to contribute as their best selves while forging their own narratives.

item.title: Are We Human - Resource Notes
item.description: Information Source: [[Beatriz Colomina]]; [[Mark Wigley]] Tags: #design #archaeology Notes: Highlights Introduction The question are we human? is from the beginning a hesitation about the relationship between ourselves and everything around or inside us.

item.title: Becoming - Book
item.description: Information Source: [[Michelle Obama]] Tags: #memoir Notes: [[Miscellaneous Notes/Literature Notes/Becoming - Literature Notes]] Highlights Now I think it’s one of the most useless questions an adult can ask a child—What do you want to be when you grow up?

item.title: Being the Beloved
item.description: Information Source: [[Henri Nouwen]]; [[Atlas/Maps/DLQ 10 MOC]] Tags: #religion #spirituality Highlights Sermon To summarize the first part of this module, let us listen to Henri Nouwen himself as he talks about the divided and conflicted ways in which we attempt to define ourselves.

item.title: Breaking Smart - Newsletter
item.description: Information Source: [[Venkatesh Rao]] Tags: #technology #future Notes: [[Miscellaneous Notes/Literature Notes/Breaking Smart - Literature Notes]] Highlights Against Waldenponding 1 https://breakingsmart.

item.title: Capitalism in virtual worlds - Essay
item.description: Reference Source: Keywords: [[Cards/permanent notes]] Relevant Notes: #metaverse #games #web3 #capitalism Notes I quickly realized how much extra features the premium members got that I didn’t get.

item.title: Check Your Pulse (Newsletter)
item.description: Information Source: [[Sari Azout]] Tags: #technology #venturecapital #innovation Notes: [[Miscellaneous Notes/Literature Notes/Check Your Pulse - Literature Notes]]

item.title: Common Growth Myths and Misconceptions
item.description: [[Atlas/Maps/Demand Curve Growth MOC]] We want to take a moment to debunk a few common myths about growth marketing. Giving any credence to the following myths could undermine all your growth efforts, so it’s important to acknowledge them for what they are: unfounded theories.

item.title: Computers and Creativity - Thesis
item.description: Information Source: [[Molly Mielke]]; https://www.mollymielke.com/cc#mold Tags: #creativity #innovation #technology Notes: Highlights to foster optimal human innovation, digital creative tools need to be interoperable, moldable, efficient, and community-driven.

item.title: Content, Services, and Asset Businesses in the Metaverse - Essay
item.description: Information Source: [[Matthew Ball]]; https://www.matthewball.vc/all/csametaverse Tags: #metaverse #content #business Notes: Highlights The Metaverse will also revolutionize categories which, for the most part, have ==avoided disruption throughout the internet era.

item.title: Deschooling Society - Book
item.description: Information Source: [[Ivan Illich]] Tags: #education Notes: Highlights Two illusions of the school system Packaging instruction with certification; linking instruction (not learning) to role assignment Most learning is the result of teaching

item.title: Do Design - Book
item.description: Information Source: [[Alan Moore]] Tags: #nonfiction #design #philosophy Notes: [[Miscellaneous Notes/Literature Notes/Do Design - Literature Notes]] Highlights salve corpus amanti, literally translated as ‘save the lover’s body’.

item.title: Eliciting Tech Futures Among Black Young Adults
item.description: Information Source: https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3411764.3445723 Tags: #future #codesign Notes: Annotations %% 1 {"created":"2023-08-11T15:22:06.041Z","updated":"2023-08-11T15:22:06.041Z","document":{"title":"Eliciting Tech Futures Among Black Young Adults: A Case Study of Remote Speculative Co-DesignEliciting Tech Futures Among Black Young Adults: A Case Study of Remote Speculative Co-Design","link":[{"href":"urn:x-pdf:feb3a75e3e7bedd28ad2ce2fddc026c1"},{"href":"https://www.

item.title: Evergreen notes turn ideas into objects that you can manipulate
item.description: Information Source: [[Stephen Ango]] Tags: #writing #notetaking Notes: Article Highlights Evergreen notes that stood out to me…

item.title: Everything Happens for a Reason - and Other Lies I Have Loved
item.description: Reference Source: [[Kate Bowler]] Keywords: [[Cards/permanent notes]] #religion #spirituality Relevant Notes: [[Hope]] and Despair Notes https://singjupost.

item.title: Examples of Strong Branding
item.description: Headspace Headspace is a mindfulness app with a mission to “improve the health and happiness of the world.” It does this by offering guided meditations to ease users’ stress.

item.title: Expanding the Shrunken Soul
item.description: Reference Source: [[Dean Brackley]] Keywords: [[Cards/permanent notes]] #religion #spirituality Relevant Notes: [[Cards/Pusillanimity]] [[Cards/Maganimity]] Notes Abstract Fostering humility in those who feel themselves already oppressed may in fact shrivel the soul’s capacity for creative engagement with the world.

item.title: Fakepixels - Newsletter
item.description: Information Source: [[Tina He]] Tags: #creativity #technology #innovation #philosophy Notes: [[Miscellaneous Notes/Literature Notes/Fakepixels - Literature Notes]] Highlights Vol. 58: Dance me to the end of love ==Cathachresis:== a statement is so astonishingly wrong that it feels right.

item.title: Finding Hope When Life Doesn't Go As Planned
item.description: Reference Source: [[Atlas/Maps/DLQ 10 MOC]] Keywords: [[Cards/permanent notes]] #religion #spirituality Relevant Notes: [[Cards/Consolation]] and [[Cards/Desolation]] [[Hope]] and Despair Notes Faust Quotes

item.title: Fortnite and Minecraft are getting kids excited about learning again - Essay
item.description: Information Source: [[Greg Toppo]]; ‘Fortnite’ and ‘Minecraft’ are getting kids excited about learning again Tags: #games #education Notes: Highlights “==I like to say we’re giving kids the tools that they need to lead successful lives in the digital age—and preparing them for the coming of the metaverse==,” said Ed Fleming, founder of a long-running computer camp based in Philadelphia.

item.title: Gamification vs Pointsification - Essay
item.description: Information Source: [[Ana Lorena Fabrega]]; https://afabrega.com/my-blog/gamification-vs-pointsification Tags: #games #education Notes: Highlights Pointsification ties to ==external motivation==—free time, tasty treats or bragging rights.

item.title: Garden City - Book
item.description: Information Source: [[John Mark Comer]] Tags: #nonfiction #Christianity #religion Notes: [[Miscellaneous Notes/Literature Notes/Garden City - Literature Notes]] Highlights Because when we stop working, we lose a part of who we are.

item.title: Guiding Principles of How to Approch Growth
item.description: [[Atlas/Maps/Demand Curve Growth MOC]] Now we’ll turn to a few key principles to bear in mind as you develop your own growth strategy.

item.title: Half-Baked Futures - Newsletter
item.description: Information Source: [[Jasmine Sun]] Tags: #technology #sociology #social Notes: [[Miscellaneous Notes/Literature Notes/Half-Baked Futures - Literature Notes]]

item.title: Henri Nouwen on Brokenness
item.description: Information Source: [[Henri Nouwen]]; From “Broken” in Life of the Beloved, 1992 Tags: #life #philosophy Highlights There are many things I would like to say to you about brokenness.

item.title: Hit the Emotional Gym - The Founder's Framework for Emotional Fitness
item.description: Information Source: [[First Round Review]] [[Emily Anhalt]] Tags: #mentalhealth #psychology #entrepreneurship Highlights Anhalt worked to dig deeper by conducting an interpretive phenomenological analysis of more than 100 interviews with psychologists and entrepreneurs to identify what exactly it is that makes a founder emotionally fit.

item.title: How Engineers Imaginaries of Healthcare Shape Design and User Engagement
item.description: Information Source: https://dl.acm.org/doi/full/10.1145/3577010 Tags: #design #AI #imaginaries Notes: Highlights embedded ethics and social science approach: in which ethical, social, legal, and political analyses constitute integral elements of a product design process as well as in its field implementation.

item.title: How Much to Charge
item.description: [[Atlas/Maps/Demand Curve Growth MOC]] The last part of pricing strategy is the most salient: your actual price. There are three standard methodologies for finding it: Value-based — price is based on the value your product creates for customers Cost-plus — price is based on the costs of making your product plus its profit margin Competitor-based — price is based on how your competitors are pricing ==These aren’t mutually exclusive==—you can use a combination of two or all three.

item.title: How to Actually Do Competitor Research
item.description: [[Atlas/Maps/Demand Curve Growth MOC]] Let’s revisit the [[Five Fits Framework]] from our Growth Fundamentals unit: (See [[Sources/Demand Curve/The Five Fits Framework|The Five Fits Framework]]) To guide your research, we’ll be applying the same framework to the competitors you’ve identified to find out more about their growth strategies.

item.title: How to Apply Customer Research to Marketing and Product
item.description: [[Atlas/Maps/Demand Curve Growth MOC]] Once you’ve identified the job that your product should solve, you can apply your insights to optimize your marketing funnel.

item.title: How to Charge
item.description: [[Atlas/Maps/Demand Curve Growth MOC]] Your pricing structure is how you charge for your products or services. We’ll cover the five most common and effective ones below.

item.title: How to Define Your Brand
item.description: Building a brand isn’t a one-time task or project—it’s an ongoing process for as long as your company’s in business.

item.title: How to Determine Your Product's Job
item.description: [[Atlas/Maps/Demand Curve Growth MOC]] The original JTBD philosophy is built upon using interviews for customer research. User interviews are important, but they’re not feasible for every company because of budget and resources.

item.title: How to Identify the Right Competitors to Study
item.description: [[Atlas/Maps/Demand Curve Growth MOC]] Talk to your leads and customers. Ask what other companies they’ve considered or used. Important note: It’s possible your leads will name companies that aren’t actually competitors.

item.title: Images of Integrity - Across the Great Divide
item.description: Reference Source: [[Parker Palmer]] Keywords: [[Cards/permanent notes]] #personaldevelopment Relevant Notes: [[Cards/The Divided Life]] Notes Your third required reading will get you to reflect on why we live such divided lives.

item.title: In Online Ed Content Is No Longer King - Cohorts Are - Essay
item.description: Information Source: [[Wes Kao]] Tags: #content #education Notes: [[Miscellaneous Notes/Literature Notes/In Online Ed Content Is No Longer King - Cohorts Are - Literature Notes]] Highlights post-content age

item.title: Information Architecture - Class
item.description: Information Tags: #design Notes [[Miscellaneous Notes/Daily Notes/2020-09-15]]: Introduction to Information Architecture

item.title: Inner Compass
item.description: Reference Source: [[Margaret Silf]] Keywords: [[Cards/permanent notes]] #religion #spirituality #personaldevelopment Relevant Notes: [[Cards/Desire]] [[Cards/Disordered attachments]] Notes Your fourth required reading discusses attachment, which is a serious obstacle from good discernment, and how to counter it with detachment.

item.title: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Creation & Innovation - Class
item.description: Information Tags: #creativity #innovation Notes [[Miscellaneous Notes/Daily Notes/2020-11-10]]: Creativity as Human [[Miscellaneous Notes/Daily Notes/2020-12-18]]: Creativity as Revision [[Miscellaneous Notes/Daily Notes/2021-01-05]]: Creativity as Resistance

item.title: Introduction to Branding
item.description: Questions answered in this module What is branding? Why is branding important even for early-stage companies?

item.title: Introduction to Competitor Research
item.description: [[Atlas/Maps/Demand Curve Growth MOC]] Questions answered in this module Why should I do competitor research? Which competitors should I study?

item.title: Introduction to Market and Customer Research
item.description: [[Atlas/Maps/Demand Curve Growth MOC]] Questions answered in this module Why do market research and customer research matter? How do I figure out who my target customers are?

item.title: Introduction to Revenue and Pricing Models
item.description: At this stage in the Growth Program, you’ve evaluated three of the five fits: market, product, and brand. Just two more to go before your growth engine will be ready to scale: model and channel.

item.title: Introduction to Value Props
item.description: What you’ll learn How to identify the value props for your product/service. How to turn those value props into the foundation of your ad copy.

item.title: Is the Metaverse Finally Emerging - Essay
item.description: Information Source: [[Ray Schroeder]]; https://www.insidehighered.com/digital-learning/blogs/online-trending-now/metaverse-finally-emerging Tags: #metaverse #education Notes: Highlights Frey notes that there are technological challenges that must be overcome to facilitate growth.

item.title: Its time to build - A New Worlds Fair - Essay
item.description: Information Source: [[Cameron Wise]] Tags: #innovation Notes: Highlights While most have heard of the World’s Fairs, few know how important they were in shaping our culture.

item.title: JBTD Framework
item.description: [[Atlas/Maps/Demand Curve Growth MOC]] There are many ways to structure your customer research, but we recommend using the jobs-to-be-done (JTBD) framework.

item.title: Kernel Learn Track - Module 0
item.description: See [[Atlas/Maps/Kernel MOC]] The Play of Pattern #cognition #personaldevelopment Goal: learn framework that will help you think in transformative ways about Web3 !

item.title: Kernel Learn Track - Module 1
item.description: See [[Atlas/Maps/Kernel MOC]] Ethereum’s History and State #crypto #technology #philosophy [Bitcoin] represents an incredibly important moment in the movement towards money as a protocol, the development of new means to create or describe value, and new media by which we can relate that to and with one another in an agreeable fashion.

item.title: Kernel Learn Track - Module 2
item.description: See [[Atlas/Maps/Kernel MOC]] The Global Financial System We hope that you can already appreciate a little bit more deeply how to make meaning from the raw material of your life; not necessarily through grandiose action, but rather as the result of joyful little subversions along the way of real awareness and humility.

item.title: Kernel Learn Track - Module 3
item.description: See [[Atlas/Maps/Kernel MOC]] Take Back the Web Why did the initial visions for the world wide web not work out quite as their inventors intended?

item.title: Kernel Learn Track - Module 4
item.description: See [[Atlas/Maps/Kernel MOC]] Internet Age Institutions Chesterton’s Fence story: don’t break down barriers the function of which you do not fully understand.

item.title: Learning to earn vs learning to learn - Essay
item.description: Information Source: [[EdMuse]] Tags: #education #philosophy Notes: [[Miscellaneous Notes/Literature Notes/Learning to earn vs. learning to learn - Literature Notes]] Highlights As part of his vision for democratic education, Dewey believed that education should do more beyond training students to fill a job.

item.title: Leveraging Your Market and Customer Research
item.description: [[Atlas/Maps/Demand Curve Growth MOC]] Once you’ve collected market and customer data, transform your research into actionable insights to begin making optimizations.

item.title: LYT 10 - Bianca Pereira - Session 1
item.description: [[Atlas/Maps/LYT 10 MOC]] Topic: Agile Notemaking #research Introduction Her definition of research: critical thinking + knowledge creation. [[Research consists of critical thinking and knowledge creation]] Anyone who uses critical thinking to create NEW knowledge Goal: PKM for research; how to turn ideas into outputs What this will not cover: How to do research LYT [[Cards/Idea Emergence]] !

item.title: LYT 10 - Bianca Pereira - Session 2
item.description: [[Atlas/Maps/LYT 10 MOC]] Topic: Processing the Literature Why do we need sources? Provenance: from source to idea…tracing the path our ideas aren’t original Strengthens our arguments We use multiple documents to support an idea “We read 10 papers to write one sentence” Sea of Uncertainty: we are swimming in information all around us If you only have a few productive hours in a day…how do you use it?

item.title: LYT 10 - Sensemaking 1
item.description: [[Atlas/Maps/LYT 10 MOC]] Encounter to Expression Walk around -> encounter -> spark -> develop insights further Practice + theory Do not go online Exercise Prompts This reminds me of… This is interesting to me… It’s important because… It’s good because… It’s bad because… [[Cards/ACE Thought-Weaving Framework]]

item.title: LYT 10 - Sensemaking 2
item.description: [[Atlas/Maps/LYT 10 MOC]] The NoMA Method NoMa: note-making sharpens your thinking, gives you intellectual assets What most of us are not doing: externalizing our ideas…this is what we want to improve on Note-taking quickly captured other people’s thoughts FOMO mentality easy in, easy out Note-making mindfully made your words active JOMO mindfully in, mindfully out Note-making is the act of investing in yourself.

item.title: LYT 10 - Sensemaking 3
item.description: [[Atlas/Maps/LYT 10 MOC]] Prioritize relevance over structure Takeaways Trust the process To build our custom PKM system sustainably, we have to go through the process of building it iteratively – over time – by using the principles of systems theory, where we allow the process of emergence to work for us.

item.title: LYT 10 - Sensemaking 4
item.description: [[Atlas/Maps/LYT 10 MOC]] Progressive Ideation process (Highlights to Insights) Read the new note Create a new note and paste a highlight with a comment or two We connect that note to something else We develop that note by doing some note-making We likely create a statement note Try it on your own Read: [[Sources/Evergreen notes turn ideas into objects that you can manipulate]] It’s not about the article; it’s more about the ==insights== you’ve gained from the article

item.title: LYT 10 - Super Session 1
item.description: [[Atlas/Maps/LYT 10 MOC]] Topic: [[Cards/ACE Thought-Weaving Framework]] Feedback 1 Which prompts above resonated with you the most? Share your responses.

item.title: LYT 10 - Super Session 2
item.description: [[Atlas/Maps/LYT 10 MOC]] [[Atlas/Maps/LYT 10 MOC]] On Flow Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi Goal : get out of hamster wheel, gain sense of control over thinking A MOC is a way to get out of the hamster wheel !

item.title: LYT 10 - Super Session 3
item.description: [[Atlas/Maps/LYT 10 MOC]] Map-making: Supercharge how you work with ideas Lifecycles Map This is [[Cards/Idea Emergence]], not “convergence” “Organizing is sensemaking” Connect your sensemaking system

item.title: LYT 10 - Super Session 4
item.description: [[Atlas/Maps/LYT 10 MOC]] [[Cards/Idea Emergence]] ![[Extras/Media/Images/Pasted image 20230222010710.png]] Compounding 3 Elements of Sensemaking Connect Express 4 Patterns of Sensemaking Emergent How emergence happens: notes turn into constellations spark-driven; serendipitious Workflow suggestions The Daily Spark & The Weekly Arc First Light / Last Light Progressive an idea grows over time can be linear and non-linear Workflow suggestion: highlights to insights Tension-resolving Often being able to resurface ideas in context to ignite ideation.

item.title: Monomythical - Newsletter
item.description: Information Source: [[Nadia Eghbal]] Tags: #internet #creators Notes: [[Miscellaneous Notes/Literature Notes/Monomythical - Literature Notes]] Highlights 24: Monasteries ==Knowledge work== regards us from high upon Maslow’s hierarchy over the crook of its bespectacled nose; it’s easy to miss right now, in light of more pressing basic needs (food, income, where to live, daily mood).

item.title: More to That - Blog
item.description: Information Source: [[Lawrence Yeo]] Tags: #philosophy #life #people #psychology #sociology Notes: [[Miscellaneous Notes/Literature Notes/More to That - Literature Notes]] Highlights The Information Lifecycle: How Three Filters Shape the Mind Attention is a ==zero-sum game.

item.title: Neuroplasticity - How to Use Your Brain Malleability to Improve Your Well-being
item.description: Information Source: Accelerate Learning Community Tags: #mentalhealth #psychology Highlights What it is, and why it’s important Neuroplasticity, or the capacity for our brain cells to change in response to our behavior, can help us more thoughtfully engage in activities that will contribute to our well-being–no matter our age.

item.description: Information Source: [[Rohit Bhargava]] Tags: #nonfiction #business #trends #strategy Notes: [[Miscellaneous Notes/Literature Notes/Non Obvious Megatrends - Literature Notes]] Highlights You can’t understand the world better simply by reading about it as much as possible.

item.title: Ortographic Media - Article
item.description: Information Source: [[Robin Sloan]] Tags: #technology #social #media Notes: N/A Highlights [[Cards/context collapse]] is the standardization of all events to fit in one generic timeline.

item.title: Our Way Out - Close Collaboration Between Liberal and Vocational Education - Essay
item.description: Information Source: [[Mind Apivessa]] Tags: #education Notes: Highlights ==[[Cards/Liberal education]]==, manifested in the form of universities and colleges, exist as a space and time for students to expose themselves to a wide array of disciplines, prepare students for a continuously-changing democratic society, and learn from professors whose work isn’t driven by profit-maximization.

item.title: Postcards from the Future
item.description: Information Source: https://doi.org/10.1145/3593743.3593784 Tags: #design #future #storytelling #speculativedesign #codesign Notes: Highlights Pre-study: desk research and interviews Design postcards based on data Research through design: participants critically assess these postcards Postcards are all shown; students pick one that strikes them and react to it Holding workshops: participants fill up a postcard, then are prompted to “imagine scenarios for the fictional world and think about critical issues related to the fiction” Maybe my thesis website can hold such snapshots of the future, then people react to them?

item.title: Pricing Bonus Tactics
item.description: Now that you have the pricing fundamentals in place, here are a few additional tactics. If you think any are right for your startup, consider what questions you might add to your survey/interview template to implement them strategically.

item.title: Suffering - The Call of a Wounded Healer
item.description: Information Source: [[John Neafsey]]; [[Atlas/Maps/DLQ 10 MOC]] Tags: #religion #spirituality #personaldevelopment Notes: Notes Highlights Relationship between suffering and vocation Experiences of personal suffering, or encounters with the pain of others, offer spiritual opportunities that have the potential to put us in touch with the sacred dimension of experience from which callings emerge Growing Pains The road to emotional and spiritual growth is difficult Because of our egocentrism, all of us are inclined to resist the process of growth.

item.title: Tags are a tricky thing
item.description: My “Fluid Dynamics” teacher Mr. Mullen always said these zany zingers in his one-of-a-kind (is-he-serious?) folksy accent. One day, we were doing experiments with water flowing down a channel, where we could alter a few of the variables to see what would happen.

item.title: The Five Fits Framework
item.description: [[Atlas/Maps/Demand Curve Growth MOC]] Growth isn’t just about marketing channels, conversion rate optimization, or any other stand-alone function. Growth is ==holistic==—it comes when the individual parts of your startup are working together, in harmony.

item.title: The Need for Certainty
item.description: Reference Source: [[William O’Malley]], [[Atlas/Maps/DLQ 10 MOC]] Keywords: [[Cards/permanent notes]] #religion #spirituality Relevant Notes: [[Cards/Absolute Certainty versus Wonder]] Notes In this reading taken from Help My Unbelief, O’Malley challenges our human impulse towards certainty and shows how faith can flourish precisely without claiming that one has absolute certitude.

item.title: The Rise and Fall of Internet Art Communities - Essay
item.description: Information Source: [[Kelsey Ables]] Tags: Notes: Highlights Before big tech shepherded the vast number of online users onto a handful of sleek websites, there was a scrappier internet—where offbeat chat rooms and eccentric niche websites reigned, and carefully crafted “away statuses” were a kind of personal branding—back when you could be away from the internet.

item.title: Training Template for Note-making
item.description: Prompt 🗺 Create a new note called Concepts MOC. Make a list of 10-20 THINGS that you find interesting.

item.title: Trick Mirror - Book
item.description: #unfinished Information Source: [[Jia Tolentino]] Tags: #nonfiction #essays Notes: [[Trick Mirror (Literature Notes)]] Highlights As more people began to register their existence digitally, a pastime turned into an imperative: you had to register yourself digitally to exist.

item.title: Udacitys Sebastian Thrun Godfather Of Free Online Education Changes - Essay
item.description: Information Source: Tags: #education Notes: Highlights It will be, Thrun admits, “the biggest shift in the history of the company,” a pivot that involves charging money for classes and abandoning academic disciplines in favor of more vocational-focused learning.

item.title: Understanding Your Competitors
item.description: [[Atlas/Maps/Demand Curve Growth MOC]] Most problems can be solved in a variety of ways. Chances are some of your competitors approach the same problem you tackle in a different way or solve it for a different group of people.

item.title: Value-driven design approach to envision speculative futures
item.description: Information Source: https://dl.designresearchsociety.org/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=3085&context=drs-conference-papers#:~:text=Value%2DDriven%20Speculative%20Design%20approach,visual%20mapping%2C%20and%20design%20fiction. Tags: #design #future #values Notes: Highlights Process: Emotion-based design ethnography Methods: Interviews, mobile diaries, online survey keywords from emotion wheel help individuals to cognitively recognize and verbalize their own emotions, guiding them to pick up on situations, actions, and environments that prompted these emotions visual mapping and value-extraction Then insights are mapped through coding, mapping, and thematic analysis of stories collected from in-depth interviews secondary research of technology and socio-cultural trends and filtering of technologies based on its interpreted value-experiences collected examples of emerging technologies, products, services, and societal trends that could indicate possible signals of change in the future (In parallel to user research activities) Following the collection phase, we placed a ‘value-filter’ over these examples, where we used the four clusters of twelve values to categorize technologies, signals, and trends.

item.title: Values by Design Imaginaries
item.description: Information Source: https://escholarship.org/uc/item/3vt3b1xf Tags: #ux #design #values #imaginaries Notes: Highlights Primary data collected from: qualitative interviews with UX professionals and field observations at UX meetup events Second, designers’ professional practices, including their values-related practices, extend beyond the individual workplace.

item.title: Video Games are the Future of Education - Essay
item.description: Information Source: [[Nabeel Querehesi]]; https://nabeelqu.co/education Tags: #games #education #learning #innovation Notes: Highlights 1. The things you learn by yourself stick; the things that are “taught” to you do not stick.

item.title: What to Charge For
item.description: Depending on your business model, what you charge for might be very clear. If you sell physical goods, you generally charge for each item you sell.

item.title: Why Brand Matters for Growth
item.description: Many founders think that their product can sell itself. Or they believe that simply implementing proven marketing tactics can lead to growth.

item.title: “The Quiet Encroachment of The Ordinary”
item.description: Information Source: [[Asef Bayat]] Tags: #politics #society #sociology Notes: [[Quiet encroachment]] Highlights [[Quiet encroachment]] is the silent, protracted but pervasive ==advancement of the ordinary people on the propertied and powerful== in order to ==survive and improve== their lives.
